page.title: The Dialogue in Hell Between Machiavelli and Montesquieu

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Dialogue in Hell Between Machiavelli and Montesquieu''''' {{cite book | title = The Dialogue in Hell between Machiavelli and Montesquieu | author1 = Maurice Joly (author) | author2 = John S. Waggoner (translator) | publisher = Lexington Books | year = 2002 | isbn=0-7391-0337-7}} (in the original French ''Dialogue aux enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu ou la politique de Machiavel au XIXe siècle'') is a [[political satire]] written by French [[lawyer|attorney]] [[Maurice Joly]] in protest against the regime of [[Napoleon III]], a.k.a. Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte who ruled France from 1848-1870. It was translated into English in 2002. Small portions were translated in 1967 as an appendix to [[Norman Cohn|Norman Cohn's]] ''[[Warrant for Genocide]]'', which identifies it as the main source of the later ''[[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion|Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]''. The piece uses the literary device of a dialogue of the dead, invented by ancient Roman writer [[Lucian]] and introduced into the French [[belles-lettres]] by [[Bernard de Fontenelle]] in the 18th century. Shadows of the historical characters of [[Niccolo Machiavelli]] and [[Charles Montesquieu]] meet in Hell in the year 1864 and dispute on politics. In this way Joly tried to cover up a direct, and then illegal, criticism of Louis-Napoleon's rule. ==Summary== [[File:M. Joly. Dialogue aux enfers. Title page, 1864.jpeg|thumb|
Dialogue aux enfers, 1864
]] Joly relates in his 1870 autobiography {{cite book | author = Maurice Joly | title = Maurice Joly, son passé, son programme, par lui-même | publisher = Lacroix, Verbɶckhoven et Co. | location = Paris | year = 1870 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k113966c}} that one evening thinking of economist [[Ferdinando Galiani|Abbé Galiani's]] treatise ''Dialogues sur le commerce des bleds'' ("''Dialogues on the commerce in wheat''") {{cite book | author = Ferdinando Galiani | author-link = Ferdinando Galiani | title = Dialogues sur le commerce des bleds | location = London | year = 1770 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8626898f}} and walking by [[Pont Royal]], he was inspired to write a dialogue between Montesquieu and Machiavelli. The noble baron Montesquieu would make the case for [[liberalism]]; the Florentine politician Machiavelli would present the case for [[despotism]]. Machiavelli claims that he "... wouldn't even need twenty years to transform utterly the most indomitable European character and render it as a docile under tyranny as the debased people of Asia". Montesquieu insists that the liberal spirit of the peoples is invincible. In 25 dialogues, step by step, Machiavelli, who by Joly's plot covertly represents Napoleon III, explains how he would replace freedom with despotism in any given European country: "... Absolute power will no longer be an accident of fortune but will become a need" of the modern society. At the end, Machiavelli prevails. In the curtain-line Montesquieu exclaims "Eternal God, what have you permitted!...". The book was published anonymously (par un contemporain, ''by a contemporary'') in [[Brussels]] in 1864 {{cite book | author = Maurice Joly | title = Dialogue aux enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu ou la politique de Machiavel au XIXe siècle | publisher=A. Mertens et fils | location = Bruxelles | year = 1864 | url = https://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Dialogue_aux_enfers_entre_Machiavel_et_Montesquieu}} and smuggled into France for distribution, but the print run was seized by the police immediately upon crossing the border. The police swiftly tracked down its author, and Joly was arrested. The book was banned. On 25 April 1865, he was sentenced to 18 months at the [[Sainte-Pélagie Prison]] in Paris. The second edition of "Dialogues" was issued in 1868 under Joly's name . {{cite book | title = Dialogue aux Enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu, ou la Politique au XIXe siècle, par un contemporain [Maurice Joly] | author = Maurice Joly | publisher = Tous les libraires | location = Bruxelles | year = 1868 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5427027b}} Campaigning against Napoleon III at the [[French constitutional referendum, 1870]], Joly wrote an epilogue to his "Dialogue". It was published at Le Gaulois {{cite journal | author = Maurice Joly | date = 30 April 1870 | issue = 664 | pages = 2–3 | title = Dialogue aux Enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu. Épilogue. | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k519820w | language = French | journal = Le Gaulois : littéraire et politique | location = Paris }} and La Cloche {{cite journal | author = Maurice Joly | title = Dialogue aux Enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu. Epilogue. | language = French | journal = La Cloche 2 May 1870 - 10 May 1870 }} magazines. {{cite book | author = F. Leclercq | title = Le Plébiscite, épilogue du dialogue aux enfers entre Machiavel et Montesquieu, précédé de César | publisher = Paris-Zanzibar | year = 1996 | isbn = 2-911314-02-6}} ==Legacy== In the beginning of 20th century Joly's book was used as a basis for ''[[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]'', {{cite book | author = Сергей Нилус | title = Великое в малом и антихрист, как близкая политическая возможность. Записки православного. | location = Царское Село | year = 1905}} an infamous Russian-made [[antisemitic]] [[literary forgery]]. There is an [[Berne Trial|abundance of evidence]] that ''The Protocols'' were lavishly plagiarized from Joly's book. {{cite journal | author = Philip Graves | title = The truth about "The Protocols" | journal = The Times |date=August 16–18, 1921 | location = London | url = https://archive.org/details/truthaboutthepro00londiala}} {{cite web | author =Kevin Schlottmann | title = Guide to the Bern Trial on the Protocols of the Elders of Zion Collection | website = [[Center for Jewish History]] | publisher = Leo Baeck Institute | date = July 17, 2013 | url = http://findingaids.cjh.org/?pID=477923#a23 | access-date = January 26, 2016 }} {{cite book |author = Herman Bernstein |title = The Truth About "The Protocols of Zion". A Complete Exposure. |publisher=Covici Friede |location = New York |year = 1935 |isbn = 978-0870681769}} {{Cite book | author =Alex Bein | year = 1990 | page = 339 |title = The Jewish question: biography of a world problem | isbn=978-0-8386-3252-9 | publisher = Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press}} {{Cite book | author1 = Steven Leonard Jacobs | author2 = Mark Weitzman | title = Dismantling the Big Lie: The Protocols of the Elders of Zion | year = 2003 | page = 15 | isbn = 0-88125-785-0}} {{cite book | author = Cesare De Michelis | author-link = Cesare G. De Michelis |title = The Non-Existent Manuscript: a Study of the Protocols of the Sages of Zion, Studies in Antisemitism Series. |publisher = University of Nebraska Press |year = 2004 |isbn=0-8032-1727-7}} Italian writer [[Umberto Eco]] claims {{cite book | author = Umberto Eco | author-link = Umberto Eco | title = [[Six Walks in the Fictional Woods]] | year = 1994 | publisher = Harvard University Press | location = Cambridge, MA | isbn = 0-674-81050-3 }} that in the ''Dialogue'' Joly plagiarized seven pages or more from a popular novel ''Les Mystères du peuple'' by [[Eugene Sue]]. {{cite book | author = Eugène Sue | author-link = Eugène Sue | title = Les Mystères du peuple ou Histoire d’une famille de prolétaires à travers les âges | publisher = Alphonse-Nicolas Lebègue | location = Bruxelles, 1849-1857 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dialogue In Hell Between Machiavelli And Montesquieu, The}} [[Category:Dialogues]] [[Category:Satirical books]] [[Category:1864 books]] [[Category:Protocols of the Elders of Zion]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Niccolò Machiavelli]] [[Category:Montesquieu]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of writers]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of philosophers]] [[Category:Hell in popular culture]]

{{Use American English|date=January 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2018}}The Washington Color School was a movement starting in Washington DC, built of six core abstract expressionist artists during the 1950s–1970s. They emerged during a time when society, the arts, and people were changing quickly. The inner circle of this new visual art movement consisted of Kenneth Noland, Morris Louis, Gene Davis, Howard Mehring, Tom Downing, and Paul Reed. The '''Washington Color School''', a visual art movement describes a form of image making concerned primarily with [[color field painting]], a form of non-objective or non-representational art that explored ways to use large solid areas of paint. The Washington Color School originally consisted of a group of painters who showed works in an exhibit called the "Washington Color Painters" at the now-defunct [[Washington Gallery of Modern Art]] in Washington from June 25 to September 5, 1965. The exhibition's organizer was Gerald "Gerry" Nordland and the painters who exhibited were [[Sam Francis]], [[Sam Gilliam]],( painter) [[Gene Davis (painter)|Gene Davis]], [[Morris Louis]], [[Kenneth Noland]], [[Howard Mehring]], [[Thomas "Tom" Downing]], and [[Paul Reed (artist)|Paul Reed]]. This exhibition, which subsequently traveled to several other venues in the United States, including the [[Walker Art Center]], solidified Washington's place in the national movement and defined what is considered the city's signature art movement, according to art historians and journalists alike. <ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/museums/when-the-washington-color-school-earned-its-stripes-on-the-national-stage/2015/06/26/83413b9e-0f98-11e5-9726-49d6fa26a8c6_story.html|title </ref>When the Washington Color School earned its stripes on the national stage.
The Washington Color School artists painted largely non-representational works, and were central to the larger [[color field]] movement.{{According to whom|date=January 2016}} Though not generally considered [[abstract expressionism|abstract expressionists]] due to the orderliness of their works and differing motivating philosophies, many parallels can be drawn between the Washington Color School and the abstract expressionists. Minimally, the use of stripes, washes, and fields of single colors of paint on canvas were common to most artists in both groups. A common technique used in the Washington Color School was "soak staining" or just "staining", where one would pour a thinned painting medium onto canvas and let it sit over time. The result would be a stain in the canvas with no visible traces of conventional application, such as brush strokes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ideelart.com/module/csblog/post/203-1-art-techniques.html|title=The Most Typical Abstract Art Techniques|website=IdeelArt|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330052444/http://www.ideelart.com/module/csblog/post/203-1-art-techniques.html|archive-date=March 30, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=March 30, 2018}}</ref>
After their initial benchmark exhibition, Davis, Mehring, and Reed were joined by Timothy Corkery, Willem de Looper and Jacob Kainen at The Seventeenth Area Exhibition of Artists of Washington and the Adjacent Area at The Corcoran Gallery of Art from November 12 to December 19,1965. The Eighteenth Area Exhibition at The Corcoran from November 18 to December 31,1967 again featured artists including de Looper, Corkery, Downing, Gilliam and Kainen.
Many of these artists exhibited at the Jefferson Place Gallery originally directed by [[Alice Denney]] and later owned and directed by Nesta Dorrance /Sept 21,1969 Washington Post Dorrance/) Other artists associated with the group include: [[Anne Truitt]], [[Mary Pinchot Meyer]], Leon Berkowitz,<ref>[http://www.washington.org/colorfieldremix/aboutwcs.cfm], retrieved June 4, 2009</ref> [[Jacob Kainen]]<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/23/arts/jacob-kainen-91-painter-and-print-curator.html], ''NY Times'' Obituary, retrieved June 4, 2009</ref> [[Alma Thomas]], James Hilleary,<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/james-hilleary-noted-washington-artist-dies-at-90/2014/04/22/22d0ae00-c72a-11e3-9f37-7ce307c56815_story.html], retrieved May 21, 2014</ref> and others. The group is sometimes thought to have expanded as it achieved a dominant presence in the Washington, D.C. visual art community through the 1960s into the 1970s. Along with the original Washington Color School painters, a second generation also exhibited at Jefferson Place Gallery.(6/69 “Four Minds With It” Wash Star; Benjamin) those artists remained influential even as some of its members dispersed elsewhere.
==Artists== [[Hilda Thorpe]] (Hilda Shapiro Thorpe) was a color field painter who made oversized paintings and paper sculptures who taught a generation of artists in the Washington, D.C. area. Other Washington Color School female artists include [[Anne Truitt]] (whose work relates to the 'minimalist-purity' side of three-dimensional painterly objects and painters), [[Mary Pinchot Meyer]], and [[Alma Thomas]]. Other works that reflect the Washington Color School include [[Sam Gilliam]]'s suspended paintings (whose style can be described by some as [[Baroque painting|''Baroque'']]), Timothy Corkery’s sharp Arrows and contrasting diffuse architectural doorways. [[Rockne Krebs]]' transparent sculptures, light and laser works, Ed McGowin's vacuum-formed pieces which he was ending and moving towards a more personal art (tableau), Bill Christenberry's neon works, which led him to deal more directly with his roots, and the work of Bob Stackhouse and [[Tom Green (artist)|Tom Green]].
During spring and summer 2007, arts institutions in Washington, D.C. staged a citywide celebration of [[color field painting]], including exhibitions at galleries and museums of works by members of the Washington Color School.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/16/AR2007011601756.html], retrieved on May 21, 2014</ref> In 2011, a group of Washington art collectors began the Washington Color School Project, to gather and publish information about the history of the color painters and abstract art in Washington.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoncolorschool.com|title=Washington Color School Project|publisher=|accessdate=January 24, 2016}}</ref> Though some of them were not born in Washington, they exhibited together representing Washington as a new hub for the visual arts.
==See also== * [[Modern art]] * [[Western painting]] * [[Abstract art]] * [[Hard-edge painting]] * [[Lyrical Abstraction]] * [[Color Field]] * [[Post-painterly abstraction]] * [[Vincent Melzac]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * [http://www.artnet.com/usernet/awc/awc_history_view.asp?aid=424172436&info_type_id=3 Gene Davis Catalog] * J. D. Serwer. 1987. ''Gene Davis, A Memorial Exhibition''. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution Press. {{ISBN|0-87474-854-2}} * Introduction & Text by Roy Slade, "The Corcoran & Washington Art" Copyright 1976 The Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.: 2000 copies printed by Garamond Press, Baltimore, MD LCCC# 76-42098 * Smithsonian Archives of American Art, Interview with Gerald Nordland Conducted by Susan Larsen, Chicago, Illinois May 25–26, 2004 http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/oralhistories/transcripts/nordla04.htm * ''Washington Art'', catalog of exhibitions at State University College at Potsdam, NY & State University of New York at Albany, 1971 [no copyright or LCCC # listed], Introduction by Renato G. Danese, printed by Regal Art Press, Troy NY. * ''The [[Vincent Melzac]] Collection,'' Forward by [[Walter Hopps]], Introduction by Ellen Gross Landau, Retrospective Notes on the Washington Color School by Barbara Rose, Copyright 1971 The Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.: printed by Garamond/Pridemark Press, Baltimore, MD LCCC#75-153646

|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/thrilling-netflix-documentary-winter-on-fire-ukraines-fight-for-freedom-to-premiere-october-9-20150806 |work=Indiewire |last= Sapienza|first=Ethan |accessdate=8 July 2016 |date=6 August 2015 |title=Thrilling Netflix Documentary 'Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom' to Premiere October 9}}{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2015/09/14/tiff-2015-winter-on-fire-emotionally-draining-for-director-evgeny-afineevsky |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]] |agency=Postmedia Network |first=Sean|last= Fitzgerald |title=TIFF 2015: 'Winter on Fire' emotionally draining for director Evgeny Afineevsky |accessdate=8 July 2016 |date=14 September 2015}} The film had its world premiere at the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]].{{cite news|last1=Farber|first1=Stephen|title='Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom': Venice Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/winter-fire-ukraines-fight-freedom-819080|accessdate=27 September 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2 September 2015}} At the [[2015 Toronto International Film Festival]], it won the [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award: Documentaries|People's Choice Award for best documentary]].{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/awards/room-toronto-film-festival-peoples-choice-award-1201597671/ |title=‘Room’ Wins Toronto Film Festival’s People’s Choice Award |last=Tapley |first=Kristopher |date=20 September 2015 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |access-date=30 November 2017}} The film was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature]] and the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] in the Exceptional Merit in Documentary Filmmaking category.{{cite web|title=Oscars 2016 Nominations: Complete List of Nominees|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/730249/oscars-2016-nominations-complete-list-of-nominees|work=[[E! Online]]|date=14 January 2016|accessdate=8 July 2016|last=Johnson|first=Zach}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it has a rating of 95% with an average rating of 7.7.{{cite web|title=Winter on Fire (2015)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/winter_on_fire_ukraines_fight_for_freedom/|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=8 July 2016}} Jay Weissberg from ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stated that ''Winter on Fire'' is an "accessible film, with greater TV appeal, but it’s also more limited by its insistence on shoehorning everything into one perspective, albeit a perspective shared by many."{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/festivals/winter-on-fire-review-venice-film-festival-1201584587/ |title=Venice Film Review: ‘Winter on Fire: Ukraine’s Fight for Freedom’ |last=Weissberg |first=Jay |date=2 September 2015 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |access-date=8 July 2016}} ''Winter on Fire'' was widely shown around Venezuela in 2017 during the [[2017 Venezuelan protests|anti-government protests]] in [[Caracas]], in which protesters were rallying against President [[Nicolás Maduro]].{{Cite web |url=https://venezuela.liveuamap.com/en/2017/17-june-venezuela-euromaidan-doc-winter-on-fire-is-being |title=Venezuela: Euromaidan doc. 'Winter On Fire' is being shown in the streets of Caracas. Many Venezuelans are inspired by Ukraine |website=Venezuela.liveuamap.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171130215615/https://venezuela.liveuamap.com/en/2017/17-june-venezuela-euromaidan-doc-winter-on-fire-is-being |archive-date=30 November 2017 |dead-url=no |access-date=30 November 2017}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-protesters/venezuelas-shield-bearing-protesters-inspired-by-ukraine-idUSKBN19K26V |title=Venezuela's shield-bearing protesters inspired by Ukraine |last=Ramirez |first=Victoria |last2=Aponte |first2=Andreina |date=29 June 2017 |website=[[Reuters]] |access-date=30 November 2017}} == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.netflix.com/title/80031666 Official website (Netflix)] *{{IMDb title|4908644}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|winter_on_fire_ukraines_fight_for_freedom}} *{{Metacritic film|winter-on-fire}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Winter on Fire}} [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about revolutions]] [[Category:Documentary films about Ukraine]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Euromaidan]] [[Category:Films directed by Evgeny Afineevsky]] [[Category:Internet documentary films]] [[Category:Netflix original films]] [[Category:Russian-language Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian documentary films]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language films]] {{Poli-documentary-film-stub}} {{Ukraine-film-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|1=Companies|date=December 2017}} {{advert|date=December 2017}} }} {{EngvarB|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox architectural practice | name = Wright & Wright Architects | logo = W&W logo rgb.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | caption = | partners = Clare Wright
Sandy Wright
Stephen Smith
| employees = | city = London | coordinates = | affiliations = | founded = 1994 | dissolved = | awards = | significant_buildings = | significant_projects = | significant_design = | website = {{URL|www.wrightandwright.co.uk/}} }} '''Wright & Wright Architects''' is a British architectural firm, founded in 1994 by Sandy and Clare Wright MBE. The firm is based in [[Camden Town]], London.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrightandwright.co.uk/contact|title=Contact :: Wright & Wright|website=www.wrightandwright.co.uk}} ==Background== [[File:T01-Royal-College-of-Art-Masterplan.jpg|thumb|The Royal College of Art Library, London]] The practice initially focused on housing projects, particularly for organisations that support people with special needs, such as the Aids and Housing Trust and the [[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://women-in-architecture.com/index.php?id=31&tx_wiaprofiles_pi1%5Bprofile%5D=87&tx_wiaprofiles_pi1%5Baction%5D=show&tx_wiaprofiles_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=Profile&cHash=58560ee3c3a3051324e69425b8c033cd|title=women in architecture: DiverseCity profiles|website=women-in-architecture.com}} Since winning a competition in 1995 to design the [[Royal College of Art|Royal College of Art's]] library in central London, Wright & Wright have built up a portfolio of projects in higher education and cultural buildings, including the Longwall Library for [[Magdalen College, Oxford]] and the [[Women's Library]]{{cite web|url=https://www.architectural-review.com/today/the-womens-library-by-wright-and-wright-london/8630113.article|title=The Women's Library by Wright & Wright, London|publisher=}} in London. Through this work the practice has developed a design expertise in archives, libraries and galleries, and has delivered projects for institutions such as the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] and the [[National Gallery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bdonline.co.uk/national-gallery-lower-galleries-by-wright-and-wright/5027485.article|title=National Gallery Lower Galleries by Wright & Wright|publisher=}} The practice is led by three partners: Clare Wright, Sandy Wright and Stephen Smith. Clare Wright studied at the [[Mackintosh School of Architecture]] in Glasgow where she was tutored by [[Andy MacMillan]] and [[Isi Metzstein]]. She was the Design Manager at [[Circle Housing Group|Circle 33]] Housing Trust before co-founding Wright & Wright. She was an [[RIBA]] Vice-President and sits on the English Heritage/ CABE Urban and Design Review Panels,{{cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/about/who-we-are/committees-and-panels/urban-panel/|title=Urban Panel - Historic England|first=Historic|last=England|website=historicengland.org.uk}} responsible for advising [[CABE]] on [[Crossrail]]. She was awarded an [[MBE]] in 2005 for services to architecture.{{cite web|url=https://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/home/birthday-honours-for-architects/138696.article|title=Birthday honours for architects|publisher=}} Sandy Wright studied at the [[Mackintosh School of Architecture]], where he was taught by [[Isi Metzstein]], whom he went on to work for at [[Gillespie, Kidd & Coia]]. At Gillespie, Kidd & Coia he worked on [[Robinson College, Cambridge|Robinson College in Cambridge]] and the library at [[Wadham College, Oxford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gsa.ac.uk/life/gsa-events/events/s/sandy-wright/?source=archive|title=Sandy Wright|first=|last=LynMclaughlin|website=www.gsa.ac.uk}} Blue Boar Court at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and work on [[Worcester College, Oxford]] were both undertaken while he was a partner at MacCormac Jamieson Prichard and Wright.{{cite web|url=https://www.ribaj.com/culture/the-care-takers|title=Paywall Interstitial - RIBAJ|website=www.ribaj.com}} He has tutored and lectured at over 20 schools of architecture in the UK, including at the [[Mackintosh School of Architecture]] and [[Newcastle University]], as well as being a competitions assessor for both the [[RIBA]] and the [[Royal Incorporation of Architects in Scotland|RIAS]]. The practice is currently working on nationally significant projects at [[Lambeth Palace]]{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/20/lambeth-palace-to-house-religious-library-new-nine-storey-tower|title=Lambeth Palace to get its first new building in 200 years|first=Harriet Sherwood Religion|last=correspondent|date=20 April 2017|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}} and the [[Geffrye Museum]], London.{{cite web|url=https://www.geffrye-museum.org.uk/aboutus/press/releases/unlocking-the-geffrye/|title=£12.3m National Lottery grant to 'unlock' the Geffrye Museum - Geffrye UK|website=www.geffrye-museum.org.uk}} ==Notable Projects== *[[Architectural Association School of Architecture|The Architectural Association]], London *[[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]] Longwall Library, Oxford *[[The Royal College of Art]] Library, London *[[St John's College, Oxford]] *[[Women's Library]], London *[[Hull Truck Theatre]], Hull *[[King Edward VI School, Stratford-upon-Avon|King Edward VI School]], Stratford-upon-Avon *[[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge|Corpus Christi College]] Taylor Library, Cambridge *[[Royal Academy of Engineering]] Enterprise Hub, London *[[Geffrye Museum]], London *[[Lambeth Palace]] Library and Archive, London *The [[Society of Antiquaries of London]] Library, London T01-Architectural-Association.jpg|The Architectural Association, London WW Corpus Christi.jpg|Taylor Library at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge 02-The-Women's-Library.jpg|The Women's Library, London 06-Magdalen-College.jpg|Magdalen College, Oxford 04-The-Women's-Library.jpg|The Women's Library, London T01-Royal-College-of-Art-Masterplan.jpg|The RCA Library, London 02-Hull-Truck-Theatre.jpg|Hull Truck Theatre, Hull ==Research== Wright and Wright Architects has also worked in fields of research including on design for the elderley, the disabled and those with special educational needs. This has involved collaborations with a number of organisations including: *The Aids and Housing Trust *[[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]]{{cite web|url=https://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/buildings/designing-green-spaces-that-people-want-to-use/10005102.article|title=Designing green spaces that people want to use|publisher=}} *The Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions *The English Churches Housing Group *Housing 21 *The Metropolitan Housing Trust *The Ujima Housing Association *The Glass-House{{cite web|url=http://www.theglasshouse.org.uk/a-glimpse-of-future-possibilities-for-dementia-care-design/|title=A glimpse of future possibilities for dementia care design - The Glass-House Community Led DesignThe Glass-House Community Led Design|website=www.theglasshouse.org.uk}} ==External links== *[http://www.wrightandwright.co.uk Official website of Wright & Wright Architects] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wright and Wright Architects}} [[Category:Design companies established in 1994]] [[Category:British companies established in 1994]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = Ximena Escalante | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = Ximena Escalante.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1964 | birth_place = [[Mexico City, Mexico]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = [[Dramatist]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | nationality = Mexican | ethnicity = | citizenship = Mexico | education = [[Real Escuela Superior de Arte Dramático]] | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = Alvaro Custodio | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Ximena Escalante''' (born 1964) is a Mexican dramatist who is known for her works reinterpreting ancient Greek and other texts along with those examining the creative process of more modern writers. Born into a theatrical family in [[Mexico City]], she first wanted to be an actress but began writing when she was 16. All of her plays have been staged and most have been published both in Mexico and abroad. Her work has been translated into multiple languages and is regularly invited to events such as the HotInk, the Salon du Livre-Paris, the [[Miami International Book Fair]], the Festival Internacional del Libro in [[Guadalajara]] and at [[Banff Center for the Arts|The Banff Center]] and the Rockfeller Foundation. In 2009, she was named an “artistic creator” with Mexico’s [[Sistema Nacional de Creadores de Arte|Sistema Nacional de Creadores]]. ==Life== Escalante was born in Mexico City in 1964.{{cite web |author=Christopher Domínguez Michael |title= El teatro literario de Ximena Escalante |publisher= Letras Libres magazine |url= http://www.letraslibres.com/revista/convivio/el-teatro-literario-de-ximena-escalante |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }}{{cite journal |author=Roberto Benítez |title= Ximena Escalante |journal= Universo |publisher=Universidad Veracruzana |volume=3 |number=129 |date=January 26, 2004 |url= https://www.uv.mx/universo/129/arte/arte04.htm |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }} She is the granddaughter of director and producer Alvaro Custodio, who founded the Teatro Clásico de México in the 1960s.{{cite news|title=Mexico Center Stage with 14 Authors at Miami Book Fair International|url=http://www.banderasnews.com/1011/entbk-mexcenterstage.htm|accessdate= March 14, 2015|newspaper=Banderas News|date=2010}} Because of her family’s theatrical background, she wanted to become an actress when she was very young, but was told that she did not have the talent for this. However, her upbringing in the upper-class Condesa neighborhood in Condesa shaped her perspective on human relations, having contact with artists and intellectuals and spend time at the movies with the children of [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]].{{cite news |author=Sonia Sierra |title= Ximena Escalante, "en el teatro siempre me siento sola" |newspaper= El Universal |location=Mexico City |date=July 26, 2006 |url= http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/cultura/49409.html |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }} However, despite this and the fact that she has written screenplays, she goes to the movies today infrequently. At age 16 she began to write stories and novels and created her first play at that time. She entered a class taught by Hugo Argüelles and at the same time studied directing with Ludwick Margules. She then received a diploma from the Escuela de Escritores.{{cite web |title=Las Voces del Teatro presenta a Ximena Escalante |publisher= INBA Coordinación Nacional de Literatura |date=2015 |url= http://www.literatura.bellasartes.gob.mx/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1613%3Alas-voces-del-teatro-presenta-a-ximena-escalante&catid=121%3Aboletines&Itemid=89 |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }}{{cite press release |title= Hay una fascinación por la dramaturgia: Ximena Escalante |publisher= CONACULTA |location=Mexico |date=November 19, 2010 |url= http://www.conaculta.gob.mx/detalle-nota/?id=9582|accessdate=March 16, 2015 }} She also took workshops with [[José Luis Alonso de Santos]], [[William Layton (actor)|William Layton]] and [[Juan José Gurrola]]. She went to Spain to study her bachelors at the [[Real Escuela Superior de Arte Dramático]] (RESAD), majoring in writing and criticism, receiving scholarships from [[FONCA]], the Sistema Nacional de Creadores (Jóvenes Creadores) and the Spanish Ministry of Culture and Science.{{cite web|publisher=Enciclopedia de la literatura en México|title=Ximena Escalante|url=http://www.elem.mx/autor/datos/15199|accessdate=March 14, 2015}} Since then she has combined literature theory can criticism with her creative work. Escalante has two children and her house in Mexico City is filled with momentos from her career and travels, such as photos of artists and posters from her plays. When asked to describe herself she replied:
How am I? I am obsessed with ideas, with themes, with people: once have began with an obsession, I go where it takes me. I am very intense, too. I have taken many risks and I dont care. A sense of humor in myself and in others is important to me. I like food greatly. I don’t like people who do not appreciate eating. I am very sensual, I like pleasure and I share this with my friends and children. I am quite impatient and intolerant, and I like mariachi a lot. I try to lead a spiritual life. I spent many years studying Sufism. I life traveling because it allows me to see places, people, theaters, books, lovers and a wonderful world. I have a difficult personality, at the same time I need much love and sweetness. I have practiced Shaolinquan and I tend to be melancholy. I have in me a strong struggle between my need to be alone and to be in the world. I spend many hours in fiction since my childhood and adolescence. Since childhood I have been this way. My brothers and sisters said and still say that I was autistic. Reality is not easy and I deal with it through paper and resolving things.
==Career== Escalante says she is a slow writer and says only in the later career has she become more productive. However, almost all of her work has been published, and all of her plays have been staged. Her works have been translated into English, French, German, Greek, [[Dutch language|Dutch]], Italian and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and have been staged in New York, Washington, [[Ohio]], Miami, Montreal, [[Ottawa]], [[Banff, Alberta|Banff]], Paris, [[Lyon]], [[Cannes]], Venice, Rome, Amsterdam, [[Rotterdam]], [[Antwerp]], [[Udine]], Athens, [[Buenos Aires]], [[Santiago de Chile]] and [[Madrid]].{{cite web|title=Ximena Escalante |publisher=Centro de las Artes de San Agustin |location=Oaxaca |url=http://www.casa.oaxaca.gob.mx/index.php/convocatorias/89-nuevas/1028-dramaturgia-entre-el-teatro-y-el-guion-cinematografico-ximena-escalante |accessdate=March 16, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402174939/http://www.casa.oaxaca.gob.mx/index.php/convocatorias/89-nuevas/1028-dramaturgia-entre-el-teatro-y-el-guion-cinematografico-ximena-escalante |archivedate=April 2, 2015 }}{{cite web|title=Ximena Escalante México |url=http://wth.com.mx/esp/ximena_escalante.html |publisher=World Talent House |accessdate=March 14, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402154129/http://wth.com.mx/esp/ximena_escalante.html |archivedate=April 2, 2015 }} In Mexico, her work has been directed by the likes of [[Mauricio García Lozano]] and Francisco Franco. Escalante worked with the Nouveau Théâtre du 8 theater company in [[Lyon, France]] from 2011 to 2013 to produce a series of four plays. The playwright has worked on various publications researched theatrical production and theory. She wrote a theater column for the newspaper Reforma from 2000 to 2006 and has written for publications associated with RESAD and UNAM. Escalante has participated in various workshops in writing and theatrical production and gives classes in dramatic literature in various institutions. She runs a theater workshop open to all ages, with one of her students, Pablo Iván García, winning the Mexicali Fine Arts Prize in 2010, for his play Micro dermo abrasión. In 2009-2012 period, Escalante was named an “Artistic Creator” of the Sistema Nacional de Creadores. She has been invited on various occasions to the [[Pen Voices Festival]] in New York. Her works have been presented at HotInk, the Salon du Livre-Paris, the Miami International Book Fair, the Festival Internacional del Libro in Guadalajara, The Banff Center and at the Rockfeller Foundation.{{cite news |author= Melissa Amezcua |title=Encanta su pluma en Francia|url=http://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/articulo/default.aspx?id=337326&md5=9657c990ba54acd8c3b92b2e95e01bc4&ta=0dfdbac11765226904c16cb9ad1b2efe|accessdate=March 14, 2015|newspaper=REFORMA|publisher=Gente|date= September 11, 2014}} ==Artistry== While Escalante has written movie and television scripts including screenplays with Alfonso Arau and Rafael Montero, she has focused her career mostly on writing plays. Much of Escalante’s work is based on classic myths and stories from the Classical Greece, (especially those of Sophocles, Aeschylus and Euripides) either reinterpreting them or working with characters and other elements, especially those she considers to be relevant to contemporary life.{{cite web |title= Ximena Escalante utiliza en el teatro a la mitología para expresar el presente |publisher= Canal 22 |location=Mexico City |url= https://www.canal22.org.mx/p/search_doc.php?ndf=2102 |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }} Female characters such as [[Phaedra (mythology)|Phaedra]], [[Electra]], [[Andromache]], [[Salome]] and [[Lilith]] are often the focus. In addition to works based on ancient literature, Escalante has also created works dealing with the creative struggles of more modern writers, such as Shakespeare, [[Tennessee Williams]], [[Colette]], [[Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz]]. She even wrote one about painter [[Frida Kahlo]]. In general Escalante’s works are tragedies which touch on love, passion and sexuality and the conflicts they generate. However, she does add touches of humor. Plays of this type include ''Fedra y otras griegas'' (2002), ''Colette'' (2005), ''Las relaciones (sexuales) de Shakespeare (y Marlowe)'' (2012) and ''Tennessee en cuerpo y alma'' (2012) . She believes it is inevitable to have plays be at least somewhat autobiographical.{{cite news |author=Rosario Reyes |title= Ximena Escalante, la escritora de sus propias vivencias |newspaper= El Financiero |location=Mexico City |date=May 21, 2014 |url= http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/after-office/ximena-escalante-la-escritora-de-sus-propias-vivencias.html |accessdate=March 16, 2015 }} ==Works== *1994. ''Vacío Azul'', published in the anthology ''[[Hacerle el teatro]]'' by Plaza y Valdez *1996. ''La siesta de Pirandello'', publisherd by RESAD *1997. ''Cary Grant'', published by RESAD *2002. ''Freda y otras griegas'', published in Cuba, France and Germany, staged in Mexico City, Paris, [[Lyon]], [[Athens]], Quebec, NY, Berlin. *2003. ''Yo también quiero un profeta ''staged in'' Mexico'' City, Lyon, Cannes and New York *2005. ''Colette'' *2006. ''Unos cuantos piquetitos'' *2006. ''La piel'' *2007. ''Andrómaca Real'', performed by [[National Theatre Company of Mexico]] and New York and Lyon. *2007. ''Touché o la erótica del combate'' *2008.''Monologs'' performed in Italy and Chile *2008. ''Electra despierta ''staged in Lyon, at the Festival de la Ciudad de México and other venues in Mexico City *2010. ''Neurastenia'' *2012. ''Las relaciones (sexuales) de Shakespeare (y Marlowe)'' *2012. ''Tennessee en cuerpo y alma ''staged in Mexico City, Los Angeles and Buenos Aires *2014. ''Grito al cielo con todo mi corazón ''staged in Mexico City, Paris, Lyon, [[Bordeaux]], Athens, Panama and Uruguay ===Screenplays=== *''Stella'' an adaption of a play of the same name, commissioned by [[Alfonso Arau]] *''[[Carlota y ellos]]'', commissioned by [[Plethora Media Works]] === Television === *''[[Corazón Partido]]'' for [[Argos Comunicación|Argos]] *''[[Vivir sin ti]]'' for [[Televisión Azteca|TvAzteca]] *''[[Prohibido Amar]]'' for TvAzteca *''[[Códigos Privados]]'' for [[Televisa]] with Antonio Serrano *''[[Como ama una mujer]]'' wioth Antonio Serrano, produced by [[Jennifer López]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Escalante, Ximena}} [[Category:Mexican women dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:20th-century Mexican writers]] [[Category:20th-century women writers]] [[Category:20th-century dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:21st-century Mexican writers]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:21st-century dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Mexican screenwriters]] [[Category:Women screenwriters]] [[Category:Writers from Mexico City]] [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century Mexican women writers]]

{{Chinese name|[[Zhang (surname)|Zhang (Chang)]]}} {{Infobox artist |name = Zhang Daqian |native_name = 張大千 |image = Chang Dai-chien.jpg |birth_name = Zhāng Zhèngquán (張正權) |birth_date = {{birth date|1899|5|10|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Neijiang]], [[Sichuan]], China |death_date = {{death date and age|1983|4|2|1899|5|10|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] |nationality = Chinese |field = [[Painting]] |movement = ''[[guohua]]'', [[impressionism]], [[expressionism]] |module = {{Chinese |child=yes |t=張大千 |s=张大千 |p=Zhāng Dàqiān |w=Chang Ta-ch'ien}} }} [[File:GuanTongForgery.png|thumb|Chang Dai-chien's forgery of [[Guan Tong]]'s "Drinking and singing at the foot of a precipitous mountain" created between 1910 and 1957. Formerly attributed to Guan Tong, Chinese, 10th century. Ink and colours on silk. 218.2 x 90.2 cm]]
'''Zhang Daqian''' or '''Chang Dai-chien''' ({{zh|t=張大千|w='''Chang Ta-ch'ien'''}}; 10 May 1899 – 2 April 1983) was one of the best-known and most prodigious [[Chinese art]]ists of the twentieth century. Originally known as a ''[[guohua]]'' (traditionalist) painter, by the 1960s he was also renowned as a modern impressionist and expressionist painter. In addition, he is regarded as one of the most gifted master [[art forgery|forgers]] of the twentieth century.
==Background== Zhang was born in 1899 in [[Sichuan]] Province to a financially struggling but artistic family. His first commission came at age 12, when a traveling fortune-teller requested he paint her a new set of divining cards. At age 17 he was captured by bandits while returning home from boarding school in Chongqing. When the bandit chief ordered him to write a letter home demanding a ransom, he was so impressed by the boy's brushmanship that he made the boy his personal secretary. During the more than three months that he was held captive, he read books of poetry which the bandits had looted from raided homes.<ref name=Smithsonian>{{''He was a Lion Among Painters'', Constance A. Bond, [[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]], January 1992, p. 90}}</ref>
As a young adult Zhang moved to [[Kyoto, Japan|Kyoto]] to learn textile dyeing techniques. He later returned to [[Shanghai]] and established a successful career selling his paintings.
The governor of [[Qinghai]], [[Ma Bufang]], sent Zhang to [[Kumbum|Sku'bum]] to seek helpers for analyzing and copying [[Dunhuang]]'s Buddhist art.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLcWyecDpIcC&pg=PA205|title=Amdo Tibetans in transition: society and culture in the post-Mao era: PIATS 2000: Tibetan studies: proceedings of the Ninth Seminar of the International Association for Tibetan Studies, Leiden 2000|author=Toni Huber|year=2002|publisher=BRILL|page=205|isbn=90-04-12596-5}}</ref>
Due to the [[Chinese Communist Revolution|political climate of China in 1949]], he left the country and resided in [[Mendoza, Argentina]], [[São Paulo]] and [[Mogi das Cruzes]], [[Brazil]], and then to [[Carmel, California]], before settling in [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] in 1978.<ref name=Brit>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/105634/Zhang-Daqian ''Encyclopædia Britannica'']</ref><ref name="Sullivan">{{cite book|last=Sullivan|first=Michael|title=Modern Chinese artists: a biographical dictionary|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, California|year=2006|page=215|isbn=0-520-24449-4|oclc=65644580}}</ref> During his years of wandering he had several wives simultaneously, curried favor with influential people, and maintained a large entourage of relatives and supporters. He also kept a pet [[gibbon]]. He affected the long robe and long beard of a scholar.<ref name=Smithsonian/>
A meeting between Zhang and [[Picasso]] in [[Nice]], [[France]] in 1956 was viewed as a summit between the preeminent masters of Eastern and Western art. The two men exchanged paintings at this meeting.<ref name=Brit/>
==Artistic career== Zhang's early professional painting was primarily in [[Shanghai]]. In the late 1920s he moved to [[Beijing]] where he collaborated with [[Puru (artist)|Pu Xinyu]].<ref name=concisebritannica>{{cite web|title=Zhang, Daqian|url=http://www.credoreference.com/entry/ebconcise/zhang_daqian|work=Credo Reference - Britannica Concise Encyclopedia|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> In the 1930s he worked out of a studio on the grounds of the [[Master of the Nets Garden]] in [[Suzhou]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Oxford Companion to Garden. via Oxford Reference Online database|year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t215.e1750|author=Maggie Keswick|authorlink=Wangshi Yuan|editor=Patrick Taylor}}</ref> In 1940 he led a group of artists in copying the Buddhist wall paintings in the [[Mogao Caves|Mogao]] and [[Yulin Caves|Yulin]] caves. In the late 1950s, his deteriorating eyesight led him to develop his splashed color, or ''pocai'', style.<ref name=concisebritannica/> In the 1970s, he mentored painter [[Minol Araki]].<ref name=ArtDaily>{{cite web |url=http://artdaily.com/news/99330/Minneapolis-Institute-of-Art-opens-first-complete-retrospective-of-Japanese-painter-Minol-Araki |title=Minneapolis Institute of Art opens first complete retrospective of Japanese painter Minol Araki |website=ArtDaily |location=Minneapolis, MN |accessdate=February 17, 2018}}</ref>
==Forgeries== Zhang's forgeries are difficult to detect for many reasons. First, his ability to mimic the great Chinese masters:
{{quote |So prodigious was his virtuosity within the medium of Chinese ink and colour that it seemed he could paint anything. His output spanned a huge range, from archaising works based on the early masters of Chinese painting to the innovations of his late works which connect with the language of Western abstract art.<ref>{{citation|last1=Jiazi|first1=Chen|title=Chang Dai-Chien: The Enigmatic Genius|publisher=Asian Civilisations Museum|location=Singapore|year=2001|page=9|first2=Ken|last2=Kwok|isbn=981-4068-21-7|oclc=48501375}}</ref>}}
Second, he paid scrupulous attention to the materials he used. "He studied paper, ink, brushes, pigments, seals, seal paste, and scroll mountings in exacting detail. When he wrote an inscription on a painting, he sometimes included a postscript describing the type of paper, the age and the origin of the ink, or the provenance of the pigments he had used."
Third, he often forged paintings based on descriptions in catalogues of lost paintings; his forgeries came with ready-made provenance.<ref name= "challenging">{{cite book|last=Fu|first=Shen CY|title=Challenging the Past: The Paintings of Chang Dai-Chien|publisher=Arthur M Sackler Gallery, Smithsonian Institution; University of Washington Press|location=Seattle, Washington|year=1991|pages=37–38|chapter=3. Painting theory|isbn=0-295-97125-8|oclc=23765860}}</ref>
Zhang's forgeries have been purchased as original paintings by several major art museums in the United States, including the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]:
{{quote |Of particular interest is a master forgery acquired by the Museum in 1957 as an authentic work of the tenth century. The painting, which was allegedly a landscape by the Five Dynasties period master [[Guan Tong]], is one of Zhang’s most ambitious forgeries and serves to illustrate both his skill and his audacity.<ref name="MFA">{{cite web|url=http://www.artknowledgenews.com/Zhang_Daqian_Master_Painter-Master_Forger.html|title=Zhang Daqian — Master Painter/Master Forger|year=2006|work=Art Knowledge News|publisher=Art Appreciation Foundation|accessdate=24 March 2010}}</ref>}}
Art historian [[James Cahill (art historian)|James Cahill]] claimed that the painting ''The Riverbank'', a masterpiece from the [[Southern Tang]] dynasty, held by the [[New York Metropolitan Museum of Art]], was likely another Zhang forgery.<ref name="WaPostMag">{{cite journal|last=Pomfret|first=John|title=The Master Forger|journal=The Washington Post Magazine|date=17 January 1999|page=W14}}</ref>
Museum curators are cautioned to examine Chinese paintings of questionable origins, especially those from the [[bird-and-flower painting|bird and flower]] genre with the query, "Could this be by Chang Dai-chien?"<ref name="MFA"/> Joseph Chang, Curator of Chinese Art at the [[Sackler Museum]], suggested that many notable collections of Chinese art contained forgeries by the master painter.<ref name="WaPostMag"/>
It is estimated that Zhang made more than 10 million dollars selling his forgeries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://authenticationinart.org/aia-archive/aia-unmasked-forgers/|title=Authentication in Art Unmasked Forgers|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[National Palace Museum]] *[[Yu Youren]]

Sackler Gallery, Smithsonian Institution; Seattle: University of Washington Press, c. 1991. (OCLC {{OCLC search link|23765860}}) * Chen, Jiazi. ''Chang Dai-Chien: the enigmatic genius''. Singapore : Asian Civilisations Museum, ©2001. (OCLC {{OCLC search link|48501375}}) * Yang, Liu. ''Lion among painters: Chinese master Chang Dai Chien''. Sydney, Australia: Art Gallery of New South Wales, ©1998. (OCLC {{OCLC search link|39837498}})

==External links== *[http://www.npm.gov.tw/exh96/dai-chien/ Chang Dai-chien Residence Memorial Hall] at National Palace Museum *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100807235814/http://gallery.sfsu.edu/exhibitions/chang/ Chang Dai-chien in California] at San Francisco State University *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110427014113/http://www3.icm.gov.mo/gate/gb/www.icm.gov.mo/exhibition/daqian/BiographyE.asp Chang Dai-chien] at the Cultural Affairs Bureau of [[Macao]] *{{YouTube|VKGCSzMNqvU|Video tour of the Chang Dai-chien Residence Memorial Hall}} *[http://jamescahill.info/the-writings-of-james-cahill/chang-ta-chiens-forgeries/211-chang-ta-chiens-forgeries Annotated list of Chang Ta-ch'ien's Forgeries] by [[James Cahill (art historian)|James Cahill]] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/161950 Straddling East and West: Lin Yutang, a modern literatus: the Lin Yutang family collection of Chinese painting and calligraphy], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (available online as PDF), which contains material on Chang Dai-chien (see table of contents)

revision.comment: Reverted 5 edits by [[Special:Contributions/110.175.214.150|110.175.214.150]] ([[User talk:110.175.214.150|talk]]) to last revision by Timawesomeness. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Bestiarii.jpg | image_size=275px | title=Zliten mosaic | artist= | year=2nd century AD | type=[[Mosaic]] | height_metric=573 | width_metric=397 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=ftin | city=[[Tripoli]], [[Libya]] | museum=[[The Archaeological Museum of Tripoli]] | italic title=no }} The '''Zliten mosaic''' is a [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] floor mosaic from about the 2nd century AD, found in the town of [[Zliten]] in [[Libya]], on the east coast of [[Leptis Magna]].<ref name="vinas-zliten">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title=Mosaïque de Zliten - Situation géographique de Zliten (Geographic location of Zliten) | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/zliten.html | accessdate=February 8, 2011|language=French}}</ref> The mosaic was discovered by the [[Italians|Italian]] [[archaeologist]] Salvatore Aurigemma in 1913 and is now on display at [[The Archaeological Museum of Tripoli]].<ref name="vinas-museum"/> It depicts gladiatorial contests, animal hunts, and scenes from everyday life.<ref name="vinas-frieze">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title=Venatio et damnatio ad bestias | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/venatio.html | accessdate=February 9, 2011|language=French}}</ref>
==History== The mosaic was discovered in October 1913,<ref name="vinas-museum">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title=La mosaïque de Zliten au musée de Tripoli (Zliten mosaic at the museum of Tripoli) | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/musee_tripoli.html | accessdate=February 8, 2011|language=French}}</ref> in the ruins of a seaside [[Roman villa]] later called Villa Dar Buk Ammera after the area where it was found.<ref name=roman-hist>{{cite book|last=Rostovtzeff|first=Mikhail Ivanovitch|title=The social and economic history of the Roman Empire, Volume 2|year=1963|publisher=Biblo & Tannen| location=Oxford| isbn=978-0-8196-2164-1| page=276| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6dgC37IqYW0C&lpg=PA276&ots=E43fgjPvML&dq=Dar%20Buk%20Ammerah&pg=PA276#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> When it was first fully unearthed and visible after the excavations conducted by Salvatore Aurigemma, from 22 June to 18 August 1914,<ref name="vinas-museum"/> it was immediately seen as a masterpiece of [[Mosaics|mosaic art]], but one that was in an emergent need for preservation and restoration.<ref name="vinas-museum"/> In the 1920s, the mosaic was restored and placed on display at [[The Archaeological Museum of Tripoli]]. It moved with the museum to its new location in 1952 and is displayed prominently near the entrance hall.<ref name="vinas-museum" />
==Dating dispute== There have been various disputes related to the [[Dating methodologies in archaeology|dating]] of the mosaic, mostly based on archaeological or stylistic comparisons, but the issue remains unresolved.
In his work on the Zliten mosaics, ''Mosaici di Zliten'', 1926, Aurigemma offers an approximate dating period for the mosaic in the [[Flavian Dynasty]] years (69-96 AD).<ref name="vinas-dating">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title=Mosaïque de Zliten - Problèmes de datation (Dating problems) | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/datation.html | accessdate=January 30, 2011|language=French}}</ref> This chronology would make the mosaic one of the earliest known mosaics of [[North Africa]].<ref name=dunbabin>{{cite book|last=Dunbabin|first=Katherine M.D.|title=Mosaics of the Greek and Roman world|year=1999|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-521-00230-1|pages=119–120|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U7Uu_Dq8oY4C&lpg=PA120&ots=lMWIf_TCCe&dq=%22Essai%20de%20datation%20de%20la%20mosa%C3%AFque%20des%20gladiateurs%20de%20Zliten%22&pg=PA119#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=4}}</ref> He asserts his hypothesis on three arguments: # The quality of the workmanship of a mosaic in the same villa, situated in an adjoining room, suggests dating as close as possible to the Augustan period (early 1st century AD). # The [[hairstyle]] of the woman figure shown playing the [[hydraulic organ]] is typical of the [[Flavian Dynasty|Flavian]] period. # The mosaic's depiction of the capital punishment of ''[[Damnatio ad bestias]]'' appears similar to records of the defeat of [[Garamantes]] recounted by [[Tacitus]] and dated at 70 AD.<ref name="vinas-dating"/>
In 1965, Georges Ville studied the mosaic based on the historical evidence provided by the costumes and weaponry of the protagonists in sections of the mosaic depicting ''[[venatio]]'' (hunting) and ''[[Gladiatorship|munus]]'' (swordsmanship).<ref>''La Mosaïque Gréco-Romaine: Essai de datation de la mosaïque des gladiateurs de Zliten'' , Paris, 1965.)</ref> Ville found that the short-sleeved [[tunic]] and the hunters with bare, unprotected legs seem to belong to the late 1st or early 2nd century AD, whereas the type of ''[[thraex]]'' and ''[[murmillo]]''’s helmets seem to be intermediary between that of [[Pompeii]] and that of the gladiator of [[Trajan]] period. Thus, Ville dates the mosaic from the end of the [[Flavian Dynasty|Flavian period]] to the early [[Nerva–Antonine dynasty|Antonine period]] (late 1st or early 2nd century).<ref name="vinas-dating"/>
[[File:Mosaique Zliten.jpg|thumb|left|Detail of musicians playing a [[Roman tuba|Roman ''tuba,'']] a pipe organ ''([[hydraulis]])'', and a pair of ''[[Cornu (horn)|cornua]]''<ref>Thomas Wiedemann, ''Emperors and Gladiators'' (Routledge, 1992, 1995), p. 15.</ref>]] Another stylistic comparative analysis by Roman art historian Christine Kondoleon supports an [[Nerva–Antonine dynasty|Antonine period]] dating as a result of the mosaic's multiple design elements. The Zliten floor mosaic employs tressed or braided twisted rope outlines to frame each panel, black backgrounds provide optical contrast and the panels alternate circular and square patterns. These features are in common with the [[Reggio Emilia]] mosaic,<!--which one?--> placed in the Antonine period. Kondoleon also asserts links between the individual designs of these mosaics, especially in the simplified floral forms and scale patterns. Finally, Kondoleon cites the inclusion of the [[Peltarion (shield)|peltarion]], a type of Roman [[shield]], as a further link in other Italian mosaics of the period.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Kondoleon|first=Christine|authorlink=John Kinnamos|title= Domestic and divine: Roman mosaics in the House of Dionysos |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yin2QKIQ-aMC&pg=PA73&dq=zliten+mosaic&hl=en&ei=tTVETZe0BcGA4Qa45Y0p&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=zliten%20mosaic&f=false|publisher= Cornell University Press |year=1995|pages=73–74|isbn=0-8014-3058-5|ref=harv}}</ref>
In 1985, David Parrish, an [[art history]] professor, proposed 200 AD as the date of the mosaic, a date that coincides with the early [[Severan dynasty]].<ref name="dunbabin" /><ref>Parrish, in ''African Antiquities'', '''21''', 1985 (pages 137-158)</ref> In a comparison of the [[Roman military personal equipment|military equipment]] of the two [[Samnites]] in the Zliten mosaic with the warriors in the mosaic of [[Bad Kreuznach]] (Germany), dated c. 250 AD, Parrish emphasizes their similarities. He performed a similar comparison between the [[duel]]s of ''[[retiarius]]'' and ''[[secutor]]'' in the Zliten mosaic and those of the mosaic of [[Nennig]] in Germany, dated c. 240-250 AD. Additionally, Parrish concludes that the mosaic of the [[El Djem]] [[amphitheatre]], dated c. 200 AD, has particularly evident links to the Zliten mosaic in terms of the realistic rendering of space on white background, and the absence of shadows and isolated plots of land.<ref name="vinas-dating"/> This methodology is criticized by some scholars, including Roman art historian Katherine Dunbabin, for relying on overly broad stylistic parallels between the works.<ref name="dunbabin" />
{{Quotation|Whoever designed the characters and figures [of this mosaic] had an incredibly exquisite artistic temperament - master of the form and model, robust and sensible; maybe he was a Greek, in any case a very great artist, who had naturally chosen artistic collaborators of the same quality, or who maybe had conducted himself the work on the mosaic. In any respect, he had inspired these characters - ready to die with great fanfare - with the sound of music and shouts of people, a life and a spirit that shouldn't die. One searches in vain for such a life (at least for such a degree of nobleness and power) in the other similar representations of gladiatorial combats (in painting and especially in sculpture) that have survived since antiquity to our days.<ref name="Munus">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title= La représentation d'un munus sur la mosaïque de Zliten (The representation of a munus on the mosaic of Zliten) | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/munus.html | accessdate=February 8, 2011|language=French}}</ref>|Salvatore Aurigemma (translated from Italian)}}
==Composition== [[File:Gladiators from the Zliten mosaic 3.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Gladiators from the Zliten mosaic.]] Portions of the Zliten mosaic are realized through a combination of three techniques: [[opus tessellatum]], [[opus vermiculatum]] and [[opus sectile]].<ref name="vinas-comp">{{cite web | author=Agnès Vinas | date= | title=La composition de la mosaïque (Composition of the mosaic) | publisher=www.mediterranees.net | url=http://www.mediterranees.net/art_antique/oeuvres/zliten/composition.html | accessdate=January 30, 2011|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last= |first= |authorlink= Robert Lorentz Scranton, Joseph W. Shaw, Leila Ibrahim |title=Topography and architecture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dQUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA104&dq=zliten+mosaic&hl=en&ei=hDNETZi9OJqK4gbx4MEV&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=zliten&f=false |publisher=E. J. Brill, Leiden, The Netherlands |year=1975|isbn=90-04-04886-3}}</ref>
The external black and white geometric border is created with the [[opus tessellatum]] technique.<ref name="vinas-comp" />
The central part of the mosaic is composed of geometric alternating square panels with each side measuring {{convert|0.45|m|ft|abbr=on}} and realized in the [[opus sectile]] technique. Within these panels are circular ''[[emblem]]ata'' depicting fish and other [[marine (ocean)|marine]] creatures ([[shrimp]], [[murex]], [[picarel]], [[conger]], [[sea urchin]], [[garfish]] etc...) in the [[opus vermiculatum]] technique.<ref name="vinas-comp" />
